columns.text: This problem asks us to identify the operating cashflow at a different number of units. Aside from this, the DOL is also asked for this specific number of units.

Cross multiply then divide both sides by $1.79$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=\dfrac{\$175,000}{1.79}\\[15pt]
&=\$97,765.36
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the original operating cashflow is $\$97,765.36$

Since we don't know yet the value for the cashflow at $43,000$ units, we can first solve for the percentage change in quantity.

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{Q}&=\dfrac{43,000-45,000}{45,000}\\[15pt]
&=-0.044
\end{aligned}$$

Cross multiply to get the percentage change in cashflow

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{OCF}&=2.79 \times -0.044\\
&=-0.124
\end{aligned}$$

Cross multiply then isolate the variable:

$$\begin{aligned}
-0.124 \times \$97,765.36&=\text{CF at 43,000 units}-\$97,765.36\\[15pt]
-\$12,122.90&=\text{CF at 43,000 units}-\$97,765.36\\[15pt]
\text{CF at 43,000 units}&=\$109,888.26
\end{aligned}$$

So, the cashflow at $43,000$ units is $\$109,888.26$

Using the second formula for DOL, we can then solve for the new value for the DOL using the percentage changes in cashflow and quantity

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{DOL}&=1+\dfrac{-0.124}{-0.044}\\[15pt]
&=3.82
\end{aligned}$$

The new DOL for $43,000$ units is $3.82$
